comment.author: 21861629@N07
comment._content: They don't really look to me like Wallachian/Romanian soldiers of the late 19th or early 20th century. Follow the links in order to see Wallachian/Romanian military uniforms of the 1850s to the 1890s: www.mnir.ro/ro/colectii/moderna/general/atacul-de-la-smar... www.mnir.ro/ro/colectii/moderna/general/uniforma-ceremoni... www.mnir.ro/ro/colectii/moderna/general/tunica.html www.mnir.ro/ro/colectii/moderna/carol-I/fotografie-carolI... www.mnir.ro/ro/colectii/moderna/carol-I/sava-hentia.html upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/RomIndependen... upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0e/RomIndependen... Anyway, as on the photo is written "Wallachians" (= Vlachs) & as the clothes these men wear are typical of northern Greece, I suppose they could be either Aromanians or Megleno-Romanians. See the following links for more info on these ethnic groups: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aromanians en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megleno-Romanians For more info on Vlachs, see: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vlachs

comment.author: 53819742@N04
comment._content: These are in all probability irregulars who possibly fought on the Greek side during the Macedonian Struggle (1904-1908) a guerrilla campaign that pitted Greeks against Bulgarians for the control of the southern part of the region of Macedonia then still under Ottoman rule. See the photo below of Greek fighters from Monastir whose clothing appears very similar to that of the irregulars above. Also note the long guns of the irregulars, most likely variants of the Mannlicher-Carcano rifle, an Italian version of an Austrian design that was adopted by the Hellenic royal army in the late 19th century. The Mannlicher was used extensively during the Macedonian Struggle (and much later gained permanent notoriety as the gun Lee Harvey Oswald used to allegedly shoot President John Kennedy).
